title: Messages in Bottles
subtitle: A hobbyist recounts discovering and tracing messages sent across oceans inside bottles.

cards.text: It turned out the bottle had been dropped eight months previously by a couple on board a cruise from the Portuguese island of Madeira ... This bottle had managed to survive its journey all the way across the Atlantic and I'd found it.
cards.question: Which sentence explains the excitement despite it not being dramatic?
choices: It wasn't a treasure map or a cry for help from someone stranded on a deserted island, but to me, it was a miracle.
Sometimes it's funny, as was the case with a note I found from a sender who claimed to have been 'taken prisoner by a grumpy old monster'.
One of the oldest messages I found was from a soft drinks bottle from the 1970s.
It's not just messages inside either.
cards.highlight: It wasn't a treasure map ... but to me, it was a miracle.

cards.text: They were happy to know someone had got their message, but perhaps disappointed that it had been found so soon after they'd dropped it overboard. For me, however, it was a profound experience. ... My family and I had always beach-combed for shells on vacation, and when you learn how to look properly, you start finding loads.
cards.question: Which sentence explains how the author became obsessed with the hobby?
choices: It sparked a sort of obsession and I started spending every spare cent and every spare moment looking for more bottles.
The internet has made that easier than it would have been in the past and I often get help through my blog and web page.

cards.text: Since that holiday, eight years ago, I've found more than 80 messages in bottles, mostly on the Turks and Caicos Islands, which are called 'a magnet for floating objects'. Bottles have been washing up on the islands since the 1800s. I've picked up bottles from senders in North America, Europe and Asia ... I've also found artwork, business cards, dollar bills... even a crumbling piece of wedding cake.

cards.text: It's a very strange experience when I meet a sender. We've been brought together entirely by chance and there are no guarantees we'll have anything in common. ... People who send messages in bottles tend to be adventurous types and are often as excited to meet up as I am.

choices: So you might think these encounters could be awkward although that hasn't been my experience so far.
